Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor suggested some optional reading and the informal deadline is weeks away.
Expectation2: Participate in civic life by staying informed, voting, and giving constructive feedback
Situation2: An online candidate forum for their district is streaming now.
Story:
I sat at my desk, the glow of my laptop screen illuminating the stack of articles my mentor had suggested I read. The assignment wasn’t urgent—he’d said the deadline was flexible, just a few weeks away—but I wanted to impress him, to show I was committed and eager to learn. I’d promised myself I’d get a head start tonight.

Just as I opened the first article, a notification popped up: “Live Now: District Candidate Forum.” I’d been meaning to watch it. As a citizen, I believed in staying informed, participating in local elections, and giving feedback to those who represented me. The forum was only happening now, and I knew I wouldn’t be able to catch the full replay later.

I felt a knot tighten in my stomach. If I focused on the reading, I’d miss the chance to engage in my community. But if I watched the forum, I’d be putting off the work my mentor expected of me. Both roles mattered to me, and both demanded my attention tonight. I stared at the screen, torn, the weight of conflicting expectations pressing down on me.
